newsitem.title: CANADA: Kmart sells Canada unit for C$185 mln ($134 mln).
newsitem.headline: Kmart sells Canada unit for C$185 mln ($134 mln).

text.p: Kmart Corp. on Monday sold most of its money-losing Canadian discount retail chain to an investor group for C$185 million ($134 million).

Troy, Mich.-based Kmart had been seeking to sell Kmart Canada Co. for about two years. Kmart Canada lost C$4 million ($2.8 million) in the first quarter ended April 30, versus a breakeven year-earlier period.
Analysts said the ownership change did not ensure smooth selling for Canada's sixth biggest department store chain.

Buyers of the 123-store retailer were York Management Services Inc., Cherokee Ventures Canada Inc. and a unit of the Caisse de depot et placement du Quebec, a government-owned public pension fund manager.
Cherokee is a member of Denver-based investment firm Cherokee Group of Companies, while York is a New Jersey-based investment and management firm.
Kmart maintained a 12.5 percent stake in Kmart Canada and said it did not see the deal resulting in further writedowns of the Canadian operation.
Congress Financial Corp. provided a C$135 million ($97 million) line of credit to Kmart Canada, which has been losing market share for years and holds about eight percent of the market.
Canadian retailers have struggled for the past few years due to an economic downturn and the 1994 arrival of Wal-Mart Canada Inc., a subsidiary of the world's largest retailer Wal-Mart Stores Inc..
Wal-Mart now has the biggest slice of the Canadian department store market, at 24 percent, followed by Zellers Inc., a unit of Hudson's Bay Co., at 23 percent.
William Chisholm, analyst with brokerage Deacon Capital, said the credit line would help prop up the retailer in the short run.

But he said the new managers might not succeed where Kmart failed. "If Kmart themselves couldn't see turning it around longerterm and making it an attractive business, it doesn't sound to me as though this group would be that much smarter."
Consultant Richard Talbot said the new management must turn Kmart Canada around after years of neglect when the chain was on the block.
"It's not impossible to turn it around," Talbot said, "but they have to be come far more focused and far more sophisticated than they are right now."

The new owners appointed George Heller as Kmart Canada chief executive. Heller is a former Zellers executive and was most recently a senior executive with privately held Canadian shoe company Bata Industries.
Kmart Canada posted 1996 sales of more than C$1.1 billion ($794 million), and employed 12,600 full and part-time workers.
